fields.headline: News in brief
fields.bodyText: Shopping centre tells youths to remove Heelys A shopping complex in south Wales has banned youngsters from using Heelys, or wheelie shoes, because of the potential danger they pose. Youngsters entering the St Elli retail complex in Llanelli are being asked to remove the footwear, as managers claim older customers risk being knocked down by wheelie youths. As a result, some youngsters have had to walk around the complex in their socks after being spotted by security guards. Gilmour Jones, centre manager, said: "For many years we have had rules against using roller blades or skateboards in the centre." Press Association Islands may pay women to stay and raise birthrate Women could be given financial incentives to stay on a remote group of Scottish islands facing a population crisis. Western Isles council is considering offering women financial inducements, including subsidised housing and grants, to stop them moving to the mainland. The details are contained in a report commissioned by the council, which predicts a 23% drop in the number of women of child-bearing age by 2019. Experts said the islands needed to stop about 40 women and 20 men from leaving every year. The islands' population has fallen by about 40% between 1901 and 2001. Press Association Haul of guns found under former police station Suffolk archaeologists who came to observe demolition of an old police station and former prison in Ipswich - because there were reports of Anglo-Saxon pottery when the jail was built in 1786 - were surprised to find dozens of guns emerging from the foundations. The haul, reported in today's British Archaeology, included an 1850s Enfield musket, Boer war guns, and 30 late 19th century Martini-Henrys, the type issued in the 1879 Zulu war. Some are assumed to have come from the police armoury and others to have been handed in when such trophies were made illegal in 1926. Maev Kennedy Duchess to become president of Barnardo's The Duchess of Cornwall is to follow in the footsteps of Diana, Princess of Wales, by becoming figurehead of the charity Barnardo's. Camilla will become president in October, replacing Cherie Booth, who has represented the charity since 2001. Martin Narey, Barnardo's chief executive, said: "Her appointment will be warmly welcomed by our 7,000 staff and 11,000 volunteers, and I am confident she will find her involvement rewarding." Barnardo's provides support to 110,000 vulnerable children, young people and their families through 383 schemes it runs across the UK. Press Association Girl, 3, chokes on takeaway on holiday trip to seaside A family's seaside holiday ended in tragedy when a three-year-old girl choked to death on a sausage and chip takeaway, an inquest heard yesterday. Ellie Conlon, from Redditch, Worcestershire, was going to the sea for the first time as her parents drove their two children down to Brean, Somerset, last July. They had stopped in Weston-super-Mare for a takeaway when Ellie started choking on the food she had begged her father James to buy. Mr Conlon tried to dislodge the food but watched helplessly as Ellie became limp. A verdict of death by misadventure was recorded. Press Association Paper fined £25,000 for restaurant review A leading Northern Ireland daily newspaper has instructed its lawyers to appeal against a £25,000 fine incurred for a food critic's "defamatory" review of an Italian restaurant. Irish News restaurant critic Caroline Workman criticised the quality of the food, drink and staff at Goodfellas Restaurant and Pizzeria in west Belfast in 2000. Owner Ciaran Convery sued, and a jury at Belfast high court found the review defamatory, damaging and hurtful. "The outcome of this case raises profound questions involving the freedom of the press," a spokesman for the Irish News said. Press Association Jockeys ordered to use shock-absorbing whip Flat race jockeys in the United Kingdom will be required to use an innovative new whip when the new season starts in April, it was revealed yesterday. The shock-absorbing whip which helps protect horses from injury is being made mandatory by the Horseracing Regulatory Authority. The whip has been designed by Old Mill Whips at Carrickfergus, Co Antrim, with the help of leading jockeys, including Frankie Dettori. In 2003 the same company designed a whip for jump jockeys which became mandatory in the UK and is now required in the US and India. Press Association
